Qingping Wu gained his B.S. degree in 2016 in the School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology. He is currently a joint-training Ph.D. candidate at East China University of Science and Technology and Shanghai Institute of Ceramics. His research interests focus on MOF-based materials, advanced energy storage/conversion, Li–S batteries and Li metal anodes. Fahai Cao received his Ph.D. in 1996 at East China University of Science and Technology. He is now a professor in East China University of Science and Technology. His research interests include energy storage in secondary batteries, C1 chemical industry and coal chemical industry. Chilin Li received his Ph.D. in 2008 at Fudan University. He is now a professor in Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests include fluoride-based materials, Li and Mg metal batteries and solid state batteries. item S2095-4956(18)31222-1 S2095495618312221 1-s2.0-S2095495618312221 Review Carbon-based derivatives from metal-organic frameworks as cathode hosts for Li–S batteries Qingping Wu a b Xuejun Zhou b Jun Xu a Fahai Cao a ⁎ Chilin Li b ⁎ a State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China b State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Shanghai 200050, China State Key Laboratory of High Performance Ceramics and Superfine Microstructure, Shanghai Institute of Ceramics Chinese Academy of Sciences Shanghai 200050 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Lithium-sulfur batteries (Li–S batteries) are promising candidates for the next generation high-energy rechargeable Li batteries due to their high theoretical specific capacity (1672 mAh g−1) and energy density (2500 Wh kg−1). The commercialization of Li–S batteries is impeded by several key challenges at cathode side, e.g. the insulating nature of sulfur and discharged products (Li2S2 and Li2S), the solubility of long-chain polysulfides and volume variation of sulfur cathode upon cycling. Recently, the carbon-based derivatives from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has emerged talent in their utilization as cathode hosts for Li–S batteries. They are not only highly conductive and porous to enable the acceleration of Li+/e− transfer and accommodation of volumetric expansion of sulfur cathode during cycling, but also enriched by controllable chemical active sites to enable the adsorption of polysulfides and promotion of their conversion reaction kinetics. In this review, based on the types of MOFs (e.g. ZIF-8, ZIF-67, Prussian blue, Al-MOF, MOF-5, Cu-MOF, Ni-MOF), the synthetic methods, formation process and morphology, structural superiority of MOFs-derived carbon frameworks along with their electrochemical performance as cathode host in Li–S batteries are summarized and discussed. Graphical abstract Based on the types of MOF precursors, the synthetic methods, formation process and morphology, structural superiority of MOFs-derived carbon frameworks along with their electrochemical performance as cathode host in Li–S batteries are summarized and discussed. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Lithium–sulfur batteries Carbon-based derivatives Metal-organic frameworks Cathode host 1 Introduction With the continuous growth of the world's population, the demand for energy has soared sharply, and the consumption of fossil energy has caused the issues of pollution and global warming [1,2]. Therefore, it is particularly important to develop sustainable new energy and maintain our fragile environment. To achieve this, we need to reduce our dependence on fossil fuels and shift to clean, renewable sources of energy, such as solar energy, wind energy, geothermal energy [3–6]. However, these renewable periodic (or intermittent) resources require advanced energy storage systems to store excess energy and release it into the grid for households and industries [7–9]. In the past few decades, lithium-ion batteries have been used in small portable electronic products (mobile phones, laptops, etc.). But with the emergence of various large-scale transportation modes, such as electric vehicles, the low energy density of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) has been unable to meet the current demand (for example, electric vehicle driving distance target: 500 km for a single charge) for energy storage systems, which has seriously hindered their wide application [10–12]. Therefore, it is imperative to develop the next generation of electrochemical energy storage systems with higher energy density, long cycle life and low cost. Lithium–sulfur batteries (LSBs) are promising candidates for the next generation high-energy rechargeable batteries due to their high theoretical specific capacity (1672 mAh g−1) and energy density (2500 Wh kg−1) [13–17]. Compared with LIBs, LSBs have different working mechanisms: it is based on the Li plating and stripping processes at anode side and the conversion reaction at sulfur cathode side, which make both the anode and cathode have higher theoretical specific capacity because of the non-topological reaction properties. In addition, sulfur has many advantages, such as low cost, abundant natural resource and low toxicity, which make LSBs particularly promising as low-cost energy storage system [18]. However LSBs still face the problems of low areal capacity, low mass loading and rapid capacity decay during cycling, which still retard their commercialization [19–21]. Since both sulfur and discharged products (Li2S2 and Li2S) are insulating for e− and Li+, the conversion reaction kinetics is limited, resulting in low utilization of sulfur. Li polysulfides generated during the conversion reaction are soluble in the most common organic electrolytes used for Li–S batteries, leading to “shuttle effect” and other severe problems, including low Coulombic efficiency, fast capacity decay, and high self-discharge rate. The density of S8 (2.07 g cm−3) is higher than that of Li2S (1.66 g cm−3), resulting in a large volume expansion (≈ 80%) upon lithiation. On the other hand, the use of metallic lithium anode also has some disadvantages, such as the formation of lithium dendrites, the volume/geometry evolution and cracking of lithium anode and the instability of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) [22,23]. Especially in the past ten years, intensive research efforts have been made in the Li–S batterie field and a variety of strategies have been proposed to address the above-mentioned issues, including the adoption of carbon current collectors [24–26], electrolyte additives [27,28], decorated separators [29,30], novel binders [31,32], and porous or polar host materials [33,34]. Among these strategies, nanostructured carbonaceous materials such as microporous carbon [35,36], mesoporous carbon [37,38], carbon nanosheets/spheres [39], carbon nanotubes [40], carbon fibers [41], graphene [42], or their hybrids have been widely used as effective hosts to constrain sulfur or polysulfides. Traditionally, porous carbon can be obtained via various methods, such as the direct heat treatment of organic precursors, hard template or soft template methods [43,44]. However, the production of porous carbon from these methods cannot be scaled-up because of some barriers (e.g. disordered structure with wide size distribution, complicated preparation processes) [45]. Furthermore, the semplice carbon frameworks have poor chemical affinity with lithium polysulfides or (di)sulfides due to the different chemical bonding nature of carbon (nonpolar) and polysulfides (polar). Therefore, the carbon frameworks decorated with nanostructured conductive polar materials (TiO x [46–48], MnO2 [49,50], MoS2 [51,52] and V2O5 [53]) or doped by heteroatoms (N [54,55], S [56,57], B [58,59], O [60,61] and P [62,63]) have been proposed to optimize the binding energy with polysulfide intermediates. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are crystalline porous materials consisting of metal ions (or clusters) and organic ligands via coordination bonds [64,65]. They have spent numerous explorations in supercapacitors [66], fuel cells [67], lithium-ion batteries [68,69], and other energy storage and conversion fields [70–72]. According to the data of Fig. 1(a), the number of publications related to MOFs for LSB application has increased year by year in the past six years, and this trend continues to heat up, reflecting the great potential of MOFs in the field of LSBs. However, the application prospect of pure MOFs in LSBs has been hindered due to their poor electrical conductivity and low stability. In recent years, MOFs have emerged as templates/precursors to synthesize novel porous carbon-based derivatives [73–80]. Xu's group reported the pioneering work about MOFs as precursors to generate porous carbonaceous materials in 2008 [81]. Furthermore, Yamauchi and co-workers made notable achievements in the derivation of porous carbonaceous composites from MOFs in 2012 [82]. Compared with the carbon-based materials derived from traditional precursors, the main advantage of MOF-derived carbons is their large specific surface area, good electrical conductivity, controllable structure and tunable porosity from the molecular level by modulating metal species and organic linkers [45,65,83,84]. Benefiting from these advantages, the MOF-derived carbon materials as cathode hosts in Li–S batteries can significantly improve the conductivity of sulfur electrodes and effectively restrict the dissolution of lithium polysulfides, leading to the modification of specific capacity value and retention. The first report on using MOF-derived carbon to accommodate sulfur was published in 2013, when Cheetham's group utilized unique carbon materials with different hierarchical pore structures derived from four types of zinc-containing MOFs (ZIF-8, RT-MOF-5, solvo-MOF-5, and ZnFumarate) to improve the cycling performance of sulfur cathode [85]. The capacity of these MOF-derived cathode is relatively low based on today's standards in terms of high sulfur loading and high energy density. The inferior performance stems from the fact that the sulfur/carbon composites are full of amorphous and irregularly connected carbon networks, leading to loose interfaces and grain boundaries. Since then, various MOF-derived carbons have been prepared for hosting sulfur [86,87]. Although the chemical composition and structure of these carbon-based derivatives are different, the target to manufacture these cathode hosts is clear; that is, to achieve the stable capacity retention and superior rate performance for Li–S batteries. In this review, we comprehensively summarized the recent advances in the development of carbon-based derivatives from MOFs as cathode hosts for Li–S batteries. The synthetic method, formation process, structural superiority and electrochemical performance of the MOF-derived carbon materials are also discussed systematically based on their types. Specifically, the derivatives of ZIF-8, ZIF-67, Prussian blue, Al-MOF, MOF-5, Cu- and Ni-based MOFs are introduced in this review. The crystal structures of some typical MOFs are shown in Fig. 1(b–e). Finally, the challenges and perspectives on the carbon-based derivative hosts benefiting from MOFs for Li–S batteries are proposed. 2 The carbon-based derivatives from ZIF-8 As a typical representative of Zeolite Imidazole Frameworks (ZIFs), ZIF-8 was synthesized by Zn2+ and 2-methylimidazole with a SOD (sodalite) zeolite-type structure, which exhibits an interesting nanopore topology formed by four-ring and six-ring ZnN4 clusters [88,89]. ZIF-8 has resemblance with zeolites in structure because the N atoms of 2-methylimidazole molecule coordinate with Zn ions to form M-mIm-M bonding (M and mIm represent metal ion and 2-methylimidazole molecule respectively) close to 145 °, which is coincident with the Si-O-Si bond angle in zeolite structure [90]. ZIF-8 is an ideal carbon source, where Zn atom and 2-methylimidazole serve as porogen and nitrogen source respectively during the carbonization of ZIF-8 at high temperatures under inert gas atmosphere. After the pyrolysis, the Zn atoms can be easily removed by acid washing to yield the nitrogen-doped carbon with nanocage morphology. It has been proved by previous work that nitrogen-doped carbon materials have metallic properties, which are characterized by the presence of a donor state close to the Fermi level. Thus this N-doped carbon enables an increase of electronic conductivity of cathode materials [91,92]. Meanwhile, N-doped carbon surface can serve as Lewis base “catalyst” sites to enhance the adsorption energy of Li2S n (n = 4–8). It facilitates the oxidization of Li2S6→Li2S8→S8 and thus improves the S utilization and cycle stability [93]. The use of ZIF-8 as precursor/template to prepare porous carbonaceous composites as cathode hosts for Li–S batteries has been extensively reported. 2.1 Effects of different morphologies In 2014, Chen et al. demonstrated a 3D hierarchical sandwich-type graphene sheet-sulfur/ZIF-8 derived carbon (GS-S/CZIF8-D) composite as Li–S battery cathode synthesized by an ultrasonic method. Fig. 2(a) shows the synthetic process for GS-S/CZIF-8-D [94], which is wrapped by thin graphene on the basis of the observation of TEM images (Fig. 2b). It reveals large surface ripples and wrinkles in the graphene sheet while sulfur is loaded into the micropores of CZIF8-D. In such a composite, graphene can act as a “bridge” to form inter-connected conductive networks and thus reduce the internal resistance between components. The ZIF-8 derived carbon provides a microporous structure for housing S, while the wrapped graphene sheet effectively enhances the conductivity of whole cathode and accommodates the volume evolution during discharge-charge cycling. As Li–S cathode, the GS-S/CZIF8-D composite showed an initial specific capacity of 1171 mAh g−1 at a current density of 168 mA g−1, which is higher than that of S/CZIF8-d composite (982 mAh g−1) (Fig. 2c). The morphology of porous carbon plays a crucial role on the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries. Porous carbon materials with a variety of morphologies from one to three dimensions have been used to immobilize sulfur [42,95–98]. Thereinto, two-dimensional porous carbon nanomaterials are quite promising because of ultra-large specific surface area, good electroconductivity and rapid charge transfer [99–101]. Recently, Jiang et al. proposed a self-template and organic solvent-free approach to synthesize nanosheets of monoclinic ZIF-8 at room temperature, from which 2D hierarchical porous carbon nanosheets (i.e. ZIF-8 nanosheet carbon denoted as ZIF-8-NS-C) are derived and serve as an efficient sulfur immobilizer for Li − S batteries (Fig. 2d) [102]. As shown in Fig. 2(e), the SEM image of sulfur impregnated S/ZIF-8-NS-C composite does not show sizable change of morphology before and after S impregnation. No aggregated sulfur particles are observed, revealing the effective impregnation of sulfur into the pores of carbon hosts. The unique pore structures ranging from micro- to macro-pores facilitate the rapid transport of Li+, implying the fast electrochemical kinetics for Li–S batteries. ZIF-8-NS-C has a BET surface area of 3052 m2 g−1 and a pore volume of 2.35 cm3 g−1, much higher than the corresponding values of 2519 m2 g−1 and 1.90 cm3 g−1 for ZIF-8-P-C (ZIF-8 particle carbon). Moreover, based on the XPS results, the percentages of nitrogen in ZIF-8-NS-C and ZIF-8-P-C are 3.417 mol% and 1.251 mol% respectively. Benefitting from the higher specific surface area, pore volume and nitrogen content in ZIF-8-NS-C, the S/ZIF-8-NS-C electrode delivers a higher initial capacity of 1226 and reversible capacity of 800 mAh g−1 after 100 cycles (Fig. 2f). The discharge capacity is still preserved at 969 and 785 mAh g−1 at 1 and 2 C respectively (Fig. 2g). 2.2 Small sulfur immobilized in micropores The porous structure of ZIF-8-derived carbon is also closely associated with the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries. Li et al. investigated the effect of sulfur immobilization in ZIF-8-derived carbon with hierarchical mesopores and micropores on the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries [103]. The synthetic process of ZIF-8-C-S is shown in Fig. 3(a). In detail, the ZIF-8 derived N-doped carbon spheres with abundant mesopores of 22 nm and micropores of 0.5 nm are obtained by direct carbonization of ZIF-8 nanocrystals at 1000 °C, and they almost maintain the morphology and size of precursors (Fig. 3b). Large S8 and small S2-4 molecules are infiltrated into the mesopores and micropores respectively. The S8 molecules in mesopores can be removed by a prolonged heat treatment at 300  °C for different times (e.g. 1, 2, and 3 h, namely C-S-1, C-S-2, and C-S-3 samples respectively), with only S2-4 molecules immobilized in the micropores of ZIF-8-C framework (Fig. 3c). The confinement effect of smaller S2-4 molecules efficiently avoids the loss of active sulfur and the formation of soluble high-order Li polysulfides. The porous carbon can buffer the volume expansion and contraction, and alleviates the distortion of microstructure and conductive network of cathode. When applied in Li–S batteries, the ZIF-8-C/S2-4 electrode exhibits a reversible capacity of 936.5 mAh g−1 at 100th cycle with a Coulombic efficiency of 100% under a current density of 335 mA g−1 (Fig. 3d). The pore width determines the distribution and chemical formulas of sulfur in carbon host, the infiltration of electrolyte in sulfur cathodes, as well as the trapping capability of dissolved polysulfides. For instance, Sun's group reported a facile in-situ ammonia treatment approach aimed at producing various porous structures of ZIF-8 derived carbon ranging from micropores to hierarchical mesopores [104]. The obtained ZIF-8-C was in-situ treated under ammonia atmosphere at 1050 °C for 3 and 7 min. The obtained samples are denoted as N3-C and N7-C (Fig. 3e). NH3 treatment enables the modification of surface area and porous structure of ZIF-8-C from the nitrogen adsorption/desorption isotherm (Fig. 3f) and pore volume distribution statistics (Fig. 3g). As-prepared ZIF-8-C mainly consists of micropores, which are then enlarged into small mesopores when treated by NH3 for 3 min (N3-C). With longer NH3 treating time, the small mesopores are further enlarged to large mesopores and are also accompanied with the formation of many new micropores (N7-C). Therefore, NH3 treatment facilitates the enlargement of pore volume and construction of hierarchically nanoporous structure on ZIF-8-derived carbon. The S/N3-C electrode with lowest fraction of micropores and highest fraction of small mesopores shows the relatively stable electrochemical process and higher specific capacity (Fig. 3h). 2.3 Effects of different nitrogen contents The electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries can be further improved by providing anchoring sites to chemically bind lithium polysulfides and effectively accelerate the conversion reaction [105,106]. Porous carbon nanomaterials doped with various heteroatoms have been extensively explored for cathode host in Li–S batteries [107,108]. Among them, N atoms can not only adsorb polysulfide effectively, but also increase the disorder degree and activity of carbon materials. When utilizing N-containing MOFs as precursor, the derived nitrogen-doped carbon (NC) materials can exhibit large specific surface areas [84,109]. N-doped carbon matrix with different N contents can be conveniently attained by controlling the carbonization temperature of MOF precursor. Xiong's group unveiled the effects of N-doping level, graphitization degree and surface area of NC as sulfur host on the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries by tuning the carbonization temperature of pre-prepared ZIF-8 [110]. The as-prepared ZIF-8 crystals were directly carbonized in argon atmosphere at 700, 800 or 900 °C for 3 h to synthesize the samples of NC-700, NC-800 or NC-900 respectively. Based on the calculation from Raman spectra (Fig. 4 a), the I D/I G ratio for NC-800 (≈ 1.178) is greater than those of NC-700 (≈ 1.126) and NC-900 (≈ 1.16). The higher I D/I G ratio indicates the formation of more defects caused by edge modification of N atoms in the carbon matrix. The nitrogen contents of NC-700, NC-800 and NC-900 are 16.59%, 10.45% and 7.59% respectively, obtained from X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis (Fig. 4b). N2 sorption isotherms (Fig. 4c) clearly indicate that NC-800 exhibits the highest surface area (1032.4 m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.54 cm3 g−1). The large surface area and suitable pore size distribution are apt to physically and chemically entrap soluble polysulfides, enabling the alleviation of “shuttle effect” and improvement of sulfur utilization. In addition, NC-800 can still inherit the pristine morphology after thermal annealing at high temperature (Fig. 4d). At higher temperature, the graphitization degree of carbon would be improved and this factor is favorable for the increase of capacity in view of the enhanced electronic conductivity of electrode. However, doped nitrogen content would correspondingly decrease with the increase of temperature, resulting in the fewer active sites for binding soluble polysulfides. NC-800 appears to show the best balance between N-doping content and graphitization degree. Benefiting from these results, NC-800 exhibits the best electrochemical capability comparing with NC-700 and NC-900 (Fig. 4e). 3 The carbon-based derivatives from ZIF-67 ZIF-67 (Co(Hmim)2) is isostructural to ZIF-8 and is formed by bridging 2-methylimidazolate anions and cobalt cations, resulting in a sodalite topology with a pore size of about 0.34 nm. Similarity in structure and organic ligands makes ZIF-67 have a close formation mechanism with ZIF-8 [90]. Furthermore, the cobalt element in ZIF-67 has strong affinity towards lithium polysulfides [111–113]. The simultaneous doping of nitrogen and cobalt into carbon framework not only strengthens the binding energy for lithium polysulfide absorption, but also improves the overall conductivity of electrode matrix. The potential catalysis effect of Co can promote the graphitization degree of surrounding carbon moieties and even the growth of carbon nanotubes, which can further increase the electron conductivity and surface roughness (specific area) of electrode. 3.1 The active sites provided by N and Co dual doping Li et al. successfully synthesized novel composite (Co-N-GC) consisting of 3D porous N-doped graphitic carbon and Co nanoparticles by using ZIF-67 as precursor [114]. The conversion from ZIF-67 to Co-N-GC via pyrolysis and its interaction with lithium polysulfides during charge/discharge processes are illustrated schematically in Fig. 5(a). The open 3D structure and high surface area of Co-N-GC facilitate the ion transfer and physical polysulfide adsorption. Furthermore, the presence of Co nanoparticles or atoms is also helpful to increase the specific capacity and rate capability by effectively converting long-chain polysulfides to short-chain ones during discharge. On the other hand, the doped nitrogen atoms take effect on promoting the oxidation of Li2S6→Li2S8→S8 and thus improving the S utilization. Benefiting from these dual-catalyzing sites of heteroatoms, the Li/S@Co-N-GC cell with a S loading of 70 wt% at cathode exhibited excellent electrochemical performance up to 5C (500 mAh g−1, Fig. 5b). It can deliver a specific discharge capacity as high as 1670 mAh g−1 that is almost the theoretical capacity of S and an extremely high Coulombic efficiency of 98.9% at the current rate of 0.05 C. And it maintained a stable cycling performance over 500 cycles at 1C with nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency (Fig. 5c). Due to the presence of abundant uniform mesopores, the ZIF-67 derived carbon is also advantageous for confining Li2S nanoparticles. Li2S based batteries can provide Li resource from the cathode side and therefore can couple with safer non-Li anode (e.g. graphite and silicon). However the insufficient Li2S splitting kinetics with high overpotential and decomposition energy barrier during the first charge still remains challenge. He et al. used CCo-N (derived from ZIF-67) as cathode host to immobilize Li2S nanoparticles for Li–S batteries via a liquid infiltration-evaporation method (Fig. 5d) [115]. The presence of Co and N in CCo-N may catalyze the electrochemical Li2S splitting and enable the lowering of initial charge overpotential. Owing to the synergistic interactions between CCo-N and Li2S nanoparticles, the Li2S@CCo-N composite delivered a large reversible capacity of 1155.3 mAh g−1, with nearly 100% Coulombic efficiency and a small capacity fading ratio of 0.06% per cycle. It also exhibited excellent rate capacities of 950.6, 898.8, and 604.1 mAh g−1 at 1 C, 2 C, and 4 C, respectively (Fig. 5e). 3.2 The introduction of long-range conductive carbon to facilitate Li+/e− transfer When the pure ZIF-67-derived carbon is used as cathode host in Li–S batteries, there are two challenges: first, the electron conductivities of these carbon materials are not high enough due to the relatively low graphitic crystallinity; second, due to the high surface energy of nanosized particles, the ZIF-67-derived carbons tend to aggregate together. These factors would lead to sluggish Li+/e− transport and insufficient contact with the dissolved lithium polysulfides. In this regard, the nanocrystals or nanosheets of polar species, especially derived from MOFs, have been proposed to be incorporated into porous or hollow carbon frameworks. This composite strategy was proved to be effective in enhancing the conductivity of sulfur cathode and preventing the dissolution of polysulfides [46,111,116,117]. Chen et al. reported a sulfur host material based on interlaced carbon nanotubes threading the ZIF-67 derived hollow Co3S4 nanoboxes (CNTs/Co3S4-NBs) [118]. As shown in Fig. 6(a), uniformed ZIF-67 nanocubes (about 450 nm) were in situ nucleated and grown on well-dispersed CNTs functionalized with carboxyl groups (−COOH) to form CNTs/ZIF-67 precursor. Afterward, the CNTs/ZIF-67 was chemically transformed to CNTs/Co3S4-NBs hybrid structure via solvothermal sulfuration and subsequent thermal annealing. It can be observed that the shells of hollow Co3S4-NBs are composed of dense ultrafine Co3S4 nanocrystals with an average thickness of ∼20 nm, and many carbon nanotubes are successfully filled/inserted into Co3S4-NBs (Fig. 6b). According to the electrochemical impedance spectra (Fig. 6c), the S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs electrode shows the lowest charge transfer resistance value (R ct = 95 Ω) when compared with S@Co3S4-NBs (R ct = 135 Ω) and S@CNTs (R ct = 110 Ω), suggesting that the unique architecture of S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs cathode is more favorable for the kinetics of interfaces between electrode and electrolyte. Therefore, the S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs cathode can deliver impressive reversible capacity and good rate performance (Fig. 6d). Even under a high areal sulfur loading of 3.5 mg cm−2, the thick S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs electrode still shows remarkable rate capability with discharge capacities of 978 mAh g−1 (3.42 mAh cm−2), 835 mAh g−1 (2.92 mAh cm−2), and 685 mAh g−1 (2.40 mAh cm−2) at 0.1, 0.2 and 0.5 C, respectively (Fig. 6e). The UV–vis absorption spectra reveal that the solution of DOL/DME soaked with cycled S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs electrode (fully discharged state after 30 cycles) shows negligible absorption peaks and its color is almost transparent (Fig. 6f). It indicates that the S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs cathode can effectively mitigate the polysulfide extrusion and accelerate the conversion reaction during cycling. The S@CNTs/Co3S4-NBs cathode also shows a satisfactory high-temperature endurance (Fig. 6g). ZIF-67 derived Co-doped porous carbon polyhedrons wrapped by reduced graphene oxide (rGO) for the application of Li–S batteries have been firstly reported by Yin and co-worker [119]. The synergetic effect of ZIF-67-derived porous carbon and rGO nanosheets contributes to an effective confinement of sulfur species. Very recently, Xu et al. designed a ZIF-67-derived nano-dodecahedral coated with reduced graphene oxide (denoted as N-Co3O4@N-C/rGO) as composite host to synergistically moderate the dissolution of lithium polysulfides and enhance the conductivity of sulfur cathode [120]. The formation of N-Co3O4@N-C/rGO-S is illustrated in Fig. 7 a). In detail, ZIF-67 was converted into porous nano-dodecahedra N-doped carbon decorated by N-doped Co3O4 nanoparticles (N-Co3O4@N-C) through a pyrolysis process. Then, the negatively charged graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets effectively wrapped the surface of positively charged N-Co3O4@N-C nano-dodecahedra via electrostatic interactions. The N-Co3O4@N-C nano-dodecahedra preserve the polyhedral morphology of ZIF-67 (Fig. 7b). The BET surface area of the N-Co3O4@N-C nano-dodecahedra was measured to be 237.4 m2 g−1 with a pore size distribution ranging from 10 to 25 nm and a pore volume of 0.93 cm3 g−1. After sulfur impregnation and rGO wrapping, the FESEM image of N-Co3O4@N-C/rGO-S shows no sulfur existing outside the cathode host (Fig. 7c), and the specific surface area and pore volume decrease to 14.3 m2 g−1 and 0.09 cm3 g−1, respectively. It indicates that the majority of pores are occupied by sulfur. The Nyquist plots of pristine LSBs suggest that the framework of N-Co3O4@N-C can facilitate the Li+/e− interfacial transport kinetics (Fig. 7d), benefiting from the enhancement of electronic conductivity of N-Co3O4@N-C composites as a consequence of nitrogen doping. The N-Co3O4@N-C/rGO-S cathode delivers a high reversible capacity (1223 mAh g−1 at 0.2C, Fig. 7e) and shows excellent cycling stability (611 mAh g−1 at 2C after 1000 cycles). Remarkably, when the sulfur loading is 5.89 mg cm−2, it can still retain a capacity of 568 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles. ZIF-67-derived Co9S8 hollow array can be used as a very effective substrate for the adsorption of polysulfides in Li–S batteries as recently reported by He et al. [121]. Benefiting from the in situ growth of vertical Co9S8 hollow nanowall arrays as a multifunctional polar barrier, the Co9S8-grown Celgard separator possesses large surface area, excellent mechanical stability and particularly strong trapping ability towards lithium polysulfides via chemical and physical interactions. Furthermore, they performed the anchoring of ZIF-67-derived Co9S8 hollow arrays onto a three-dimensional graphene foam (grown by chemical vapor deposition) as an efficient cathode host (Co9S8-3DGF) for long-life Li–S batteries [122]. The synthetic strategy of Co9S8-3DGF/S electrode and its comparison with 3DGF in terms of charge/discharge process are shown in Fig. 8(a). The SEM images of Co9S8-3DGF displayed a typical array morphology and a uniform coating with hollow structure on 3DGF (Fig. 8b). After sulfur impregnation into Co9S8-3DGF, the morphology of nanowall arrays is still preserved in Co9S8-3DGF/S (Fig. 8c). Such a unique architecture with an excellent interfacial contact between sulfur-Co9S8 and 3DGF can promote the fast diffusion of lithium polysulfides on the Co9S8 surface to the highly conductive graphene surface. As a result, strong entrapment (by Co9S8) and fast electron transfer (by 3DGF) for polysulfide conversion can be simultaneously realized, avoiding the undesired accumulation of polysulfides and improving their utilization. The binder-free, free-standing Co9S8-3DGF/S cathode can deliver an excellent rate performance (670 mAh g−1 at 2 C), remarkably high areal capacity of 10.9 mAh cm−2 even under a very high sulfur loading (10.4 mg cm−2) and sulfur content (86.9 wt%) as shown in Fig. 8(d). 4 The carbon-based derivatives from bimetallic ZIFs A large number of studies indicate that ZIF-8 has good thermal stability and high porosity, and ZIF-67 has tunable pore structure and catalytic activity [88,123–126]. According to previous reports, both high N content and highly graphitized structure are difficult to be realized at the same time because the N content largely decreases during the graphitization of carbon at high temperature [127]. Porous carbon derived from pure ZIF-8 crystals has relatively high N content and large surface area, and however it is in an amorphous state. In contrast, porous carbon derived from ZIF-67 crystals possesses highly graphitic walls with good conductivity due to the catalytic graphitization effect of well-dispersed Co species in the parent ZIF-67 crystals, but with the compromise of surface area and N content [128]. Very recently, Chen and co-authors combined with the merits of ZIF-8 and ZIF-67 and prepared a multifunctional carbon hybrid consisting of bimetallic-ZIFs-derived (Co/Zn) nitrogen-doped porous carbon, which was further anchored on graphene sheets (NPC/G) [129]. The schematic of fabrication process of NPC/G is shown in Fig. 9(a). This composite was obtained by carbonizing the bimetallic ZIF nanoparticles on graphene oxide (ZIF/GO). This anchoring of ZIFs on GO was achieved based on the electrostatic interaction between electropositive metallic ions of ZIF and electronegative oxygen functional groups of GO. Such a hybrid of ZIFs-derived carbons gives rise to both the effects of physical confinement and chemical adsorption toward polysulfides owing to its abundant pore structure and sufficient nitrogen doping. The highly conductive graphene not only provides an interconnected conductive framework to facilitate fast Li+/e transport, but also serves as a building unit to hold the bimetallic-ZIFs-derived carbon moieties. The S-NPC/G as Li–S cathode exhibits a high specific capacity of 1372 mAh g−1 with superior cycling stability over 300 cycles at 0.1C as well as an excellent cycling response to continuous variation of current densities (high capacities of 1332, 932, 858, and 786 mAh g−1 at 0.1, 0.2, 0.5, and 1C, respectively) (Fig. 9b). Actually, the zinc element in ZIF-8 and cobalt element in ZIF-67 serve as the nanocage template and functional modifier, respectively, during the carbonization process. Liu et al. reported the novel 2D bimetallic-ZIF (Co/Zn) derived porous carbon nanosheets (Co/N-PCNSs) benefiting from graphene oxide (GO) as 2D nanosheet substrate. Therein both poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP) and Co/Zn-ZIFs serve as the N-doped carbon source as shown in Fig. 9(c) [130]. The TEM images of Co/N-PCNSs reveal the homogeneous distribution of nanocages in the nanosheets with small Co nanoparticles embedded in the carbon skeletons (Fig. 9d, e). The HRTEM analysis further indicates that these Co nanoparticles are encapsulated in graphitic carbon layers, which result from the catalytic graphitization of amorphous carbon by in-situ obtained Co nanoparticles at high temperature (Fig. 9f). The stable Co nanoparticles can work synergistically with N heteroatoms to greatly enhance the reservation and reversibility of soluble polysulfides and to accelerate the conversion reaction kinetics of sulfur cathode. The Co/N-PCNSs based Li–S batteries demonstrated superior cycling stability over 400 cycles with high capacity of 411 mAh g−1 at high current density of 5 C as well as excellent rate performance with reversible capacities of 871, 777, 683, 594, 549, and 520 mAh g−1 at 0.5, 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5 C, respectively (Fig. 9g). 5 The carbon-based derivatives from Prussian-blue and Prussian blue analogues Prussian blue has a cubic framework with the formula of Fe4 III[FeII(CN)6]3 and contains polar FeII-C-N-FeIII units [131,132], which are soft Lewis acids and can thus coordinate readily with polysulfide anions via the Lewis acid-base interaction [133]. Prussian blue is also of low cost, environmentally friendly and easy to synthesize. In recent years, Prussian blue exhibits many interesting physicochemical functions, which make it widely applied in catalysis and energy fields [134–137]. It has been demonstrated that Prussian blue has a strong interaction with polysulfides to suppress their dissolution into electrolyte via Lewis acid-base bonding and pore confining effects in high-performance Li–S batteries [138]. However, when the pure Prussian blue (or Prussian blue analogues) is used as sulfur host, the rate performance cannot meet the practical demand because of its poor electroconductivity. To address this issue, it is desired to pyrolyze Prussian blue into functional carbon material. Su et al. reported a facile one-step method to synthesize Fe3C@N-GE-CNTs hybrids from Prussian blue [139]. The synthesis process is illustrated in Fig. 10(a), where the Fe3C@N-GE-CNTs hybrids were obtained after annealing the dehydrated commercial Na4Fe(CN)6•10H2O at 900 °C for 3 h in nitrogen atmosphere. The FESEM image revealed that the products with hierarchical structure consisted of graphene nanosheets and carbon nanotubes (Fig. 10b). These carbon nanotubes have a diameter of around 100 nm, connecting to graphene layer with junctions (Fig. 10c). Furthermore, Fe3C nanoparticles can be observed on the tips of carbon nanotubes because the as-formed Fe3C can act as nanocatalyst to grow carbon nanotubes. The unique architecture combining 2D graphene and 1D carbon nanotube is propitious to improve the electron conductivity, prevent the dissolution of polysulfides, minimize the shuttle effect, and facilitate the penetration and diffusion of electrolyte. Furthermore, the doped nitrogen atoms introduce more defects and active sites to the carbon framework and effectively trap lithium polysulfides on these electroactive sites. After infiltrating sulfur, the S@Fe x S@N-GE-CNTs composites demonstrated an excellent cycling stability over 1000 cycles (629, 495 and 332 mAh g−1 at 1, 2 and 5 C respectively) and a high rate capability (712, 458 and 220 mAh g−1 at 2, 5 and 10 C respectively) (Fig. 10d). As the derivative of Prussian blue, Prussian blue analogues possess the structures based on a simple cubic M[M′(CN)6] framework, in which octahedral [M′(CN)6] n − complexes are linked via octahedrally coordinated and nitrogen-bound M n + ions [140]. Prussian blue analogues have been widely studied as electrode materials for secondary batteries and supercapacitors due to their structural superiority and potential for fast charge and discharge [141–143]. The sodium iron cyanide (Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6)]) with open framework structure was synthesized via a facile solution method to confine polysulfides by Su and co-authors [144]. The as-prepared Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6 has a cubic morphology with highly uniform size of ≈ 150 nm, as shown in the FESEM image of Fig. 10(e). According to the Rietveld-refined XRD data, the refined structure of Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6 with large interstitial space of 5.27 × 5.27 Å2 exhibits that iron ions are located inside the Fe[Fe(CN)6]2− complex and are coordinated by six equivalent CN− groups, leading to the formation of octahedron (Fig. 10f). The transition metal centers can serve as the Lewis acid sites with high affinity to the negatively charged polysulfide anions. It enables the reduction of polysulfide diffusion out of the cathode and the minimization of shuttling effect. After combining with conductive PEDOT as electron wires, the S@Na2Fe[Fe(CN)6)]@PEDOT composite electrode exhibited the high initial capacities of 1147, 1065, 1001, 819 and 683 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1, 2 and 5 C, respectively and remarkable cycling stability (Fig. 10g). In recent years, the synthesis of sulfur hosts with unique morphology by using Prussian blue analogues as precursors has been showing a rising trend. Hu et al. constructed double-shelled heterostructure NiONiCo2O4@C hollow nanocages via annealing Ni-Co Prussian blue analogues (PBA, Ni3[Co(CN)6]2) nanocube precursors [145]. The corresponding synthetic approach to S/NiO-NiCo2O4@C composite is schematically shown in Fig. 11(a). In detail, Ni-Co PBA nanocubes are first converted into Ni-Co mixed oxide nanocages by a facile calcination treatment in air at 450 °C. Then a uniform carbon layer derived from glucose is coated onto the surface of NiO-NiCo2O4 heterostructure nanocages by a simple hydrothermal process (Fig. 11b). After a melt-diffusion process, sulfur was successfully introduced into the NiO-NiCo2O4@C hollow nanocages (Fig. 11c). This novel composite as Li–S cathode host has the structure merits: (1) The hollow structure can not only provide sufficient space for loading sulfur, but also mitigate the volumetric variation of sulfur based electrode during cycling; (2) NiO-NiCo2O4 heterostructure nanocages can effectively prevent polysulfide diffusion and accelerate the charge transfer for polysulfide conversion reactions, thus remitting the shuttling effect of polysulfides; (3) The outside carbon layer can improve the electrical conductivity for better electron transport during cycling. Benefiting from these superiorities, the S/NiO-NiCo2O4@C electrode delivers high discharge capacities of 1063.2, 920, 821.7 and 697.9 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C respectively and stable cycling life up to 500 cycles at 0.5 C with a very low capacity decay rate of only ≈ 0.059% per cycle (Fig. 11d). The uniform pomegranate-like microclusters, consisting of inlaid ultrafine Co nanoparticles in nitrogen-doped carbon subunits, was synthesized via carbonization of a Prussian blue analogue by Wang and co-workers [146], as shown in the illustration of Fig. 11(e). The Zn3[Co(CN)6]2/PVP-F127 composite precursor was firstly synthesized through a facile ultrasonic method and it was then heated at 800 °C in Ar atmosphere to yield the pomegranate-like Co-NPC-MCs. In this structure, uniformly distributed Co nanoparticles were embedded in highly conductive graphitic porous N-doped carbon networks. The hierarchical micro-mesoporous structures effectively accommodated sulfur and restricted the diffusion of lithium polysulfides during cycling (Fig. 11f). The uniform Co nanoparticles and nitrogen species not only provide chemical bonding with lithium polysulfides but also improve the conductivity of sulfur electrode. The S/Co-NPC-MCs cathode exhibited a high initial capacity of 1192 and 941 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles at 0.5 C, as well as excellent rate capacities of 905 and 823 mAh g−1 at high rates of 1 and 2 C over 400 cycles respectively (Fig. 11g). 6 The carbon-based derivatives from other MOFs 6.1 Rod-like porous carbon derived from Al-PCP Porous carbon derived from Al-PCP (Al(OH)(1,4-naphthalenedicarboxylate)) has great appeal in the fields of sensing, energy-storage and catalysis due to its robust framework, high surface area and large pore volume [147–149]. The french-fries-like hierarchical porous carbon was prepared through one-step carbonization of Al-PCP and the following removal of Al species with HF by Yang and co-author, as illustrated in Fig. 12(a) [150]. The resulting FLHPC reserves the initial french-fries-like morphology compared to Al-MOF, but exhibits obvious large layered cracks because of the carbonization and HF etching processes. These cracks are beneficial for the infiltration of electrolyte during charge-discharge process (Fig. 12b). The morphology of S/FLHPC is retained after sulfur impregnation and shows no obvious sulfur particles (Fig. 12c). Such a french-fries-like carbon with hierarchical porous structure could effectively confine the polysulfides in the micro- and mesopores and leave enough free volume to accommodate the volume expansion from sulfur to Li2S. As a result, the S/FLHPC electrode exhibited a high initial discharge capacity of 1206 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C and excellent rate capability of 763 mAh g−1 up to 2 C (Fig. 12d). The electrochemical charge transfer kinetics for the Al-PCP-derived porous electrodes is significantly limited owing to the poor electron conductivity due to low graphitization degree and poor contact between Al-PCP-derived particles. To solve this problem, Li et al. designed CNTs wrapped Al-PCP-derived porous carbon sponges (CNTs/MOFs-C) through an electrostatic interaction between positively charged Al-PCP-C and negatively charged CNTs [151]. In addition, a novel kind of Al2(OH)2.76F3.24 hydroxyhalide nanoparticle with hydroxyl functional groups and polar bonds is introduced to synthesize CNTs/MOFs-C/Al2(OH)2.76F3.24 composite. The synthetic route for CNTs/MOFs-C/Al2(OH)2.76F3.24/S hybrid and the sulfur immobilization mechanism are shown in Fig. 12(e). The Al-PCP precursor was annealed into Al-PCP-C at 800 °C under Ar atmosphere and then the residual Al2O3 was fluorinated by HF into Al2(OH)2.76F3.24 hydroxyhalide nanoparticles. The electrostatic interaction between the modified Al-PCP-C positively charged by PDDA and the modified CNTs negatively charged by concentrated H2SO4 leads to the self-assembly of both the carbons. The 3D hierarchical hybrids with 3D interconnected charge transfer pathways and interlinked electrolyte diffusion channels could achieve an excellent performance for Li–S batteries. The TEM image of CNTs/MOFs-C/Al2(OH)2.76F3.24/S hybrids showed that CNTs uniformly wrap 3D Al-PCP-C (Fig. 12f). This unique structure could enable rapid charge transport from CNTs to Al-PCP-C. The chemisorption between Al2(OH)2.76F3.24 particles and lithium polysulfides contributed by the hydroxyl functional groups and Al-F polar bonds can significantly immobilize polysulfide intermediates. Therefore, the Al-PCP-C, CNTs and Al2(OH)2.76F3.24 particles confine the polysulfide intermediates synergistically, leading to the suppressed shuttle effect and low polarization. The CNTs/MOFs-C/Al2(OH)2.76F3.24/S electrode showed high specific capacities of 948, 889 and 806 mAh g−1 at 300th cycle under the current densities of 200, 500 and 1000 mA g−1 respectively. A ultra-long cycling life of 2000 cycles at a high current density of 2 A g−1 was achieved with a specific capacity of 719 mAh g−1 and a coulombic efficiency of approximately 100% (Fig. 12g). 6.2 Mesoporous carbon derived from MOF-5 MOF-5 (Zn4O(BDC)3) has excellent thermal stability and high porosity [152,153]. The uniform polyhedral shape and crystal structure of MOF-5 particles are shown in Fig. 13(a, b). Highly porous carbon derived from MOF-5 exhibited good performance in supercapacitor [154], ORR electrocatalysts [155], sodium-ion batteries [156], and so on. MOF-5-derived activated mesoporous carbon polyhedron/sulfur composite (AMCP-950/S) was designed and synthesized by Cai et al [157]. The MOF-5 was carbonized in an inert gas and then underwent KOH activation to produce AMCP-950, which has uniform sponge-like morphology, abundant mesoporous structure and huge large specific surface areas of 2211.1 m2 g−1 as shown in Fig. 13(c). The abundant mesoporous structure as polysulfide storehouse can reduce the loss of active material and promote electrolyte penetration and Li ion diffusion. AMCP-950/S as Li–S cathode showed excellent electrochemical performance with a high initial capacity of 1274.0 mAh g−1 and over 81.7% capacity retention after 50 cycles at 0.2 C (Fig. 13d). Bao and co-author synthesized a hybrid of metal carbide and mesoporous carbon (Ti3C2T x @Meso-C) with a hierarchical architecture by using MXene and mesoporous MOF matrix (Ti3C2X x @Meso-MOF-5, X x  ≈ F x OH y O z ) as both the template and precursor [158]. The synthesis procedure of Ti3C2T x @Meso-C/S composites is illustrated in Fig. 13e. Typically, the Ti3C2X x @Meso-MOF-5 composites were synthesized by a solvent reaction and then the composite precursor was heat-treated to obtain Ti3C2T x @Meso-C. The 2D Ti3C2T x nanosheets are uniformly distributed and embedded in the frameworks of Meso-C, which can effectively stabilize Ti3C2T x nanosheets through the strong hydrophilic surface of Ti3C2T x and prevent the restacking of Ti3C2T x nanosheets (Fig. 13f). This hybrid matrix of Ti3C2T x @Meso-C was filled by amorphous sulfur during the melt process at 155 °C (Fig. 13g). The Ti3C2T x @Meso-C hybrid nanocomposites can provide conductive networks and Li+ diffusion pathways when applied as cathode host in Li–S batteries. Moreover, the active hydrophilic surfaces of exfoliated-Ti3C2T x nanosheets can effectively trap polysulfides. The mesoporous matrix of Ti3C2T x @Meso-C can slow down the polysulfide diffusion out of the pores during cycling due to the strong physical adsorption. As a result, the Ti3C2T x @Meso-C/S electrode delivered a high reversible capacity of 704.6 mAh g−1 after 300 cycles at 0.5 C and good rate performance up to 5 C (Fig. 13g). 6.3 The derivatives of Cu-based MOFs facilitate Li+/e− transfer The e− transfer within bulk electrode is significantly limited owing to the “point contact” transfer mode between powder particles [159–161]. Recently, one-dimensional (1D) oriented carbon materials have shown great promising in promoting the C-rate performance of Li–S batteries. The cross-linked hierarchical porous carbon fibers (CHPCF) with 1D orientation and multi-scale pore distribution were fabricated from a well-designed Cu-MOF ([Cu(BTC − H2)2  − (H2O)2]•3H2O) with unique morphology and applied as the sulfur host material by Yang and co-workers [162]. The synthesis process is illustrated in Fig. 14(a). CHPCF can be prepared by the carbonization of microporous Cu-MOF precursor and following heat-treatment with KOH at 700 °C under Ar atmosphere. Fig. 14(b, c) shows the unique fibers structure full of hierarchical pores. Therein the copper ions are reduced to corresponding Cu and Cu2O particles that act as“localized” inner templates to form meso‑pores. In addition, macro-pores can also be formed due to the synergic effect of 1,3,5-BTC decomposition and gas activation during carbonization. The unique structure is suitable for Li–S batteries with a high C-rate, since the macro-pores among the ordered fibers and the meso‑pores within the fibers can facilitate Li+ transportation as well as provide a large surface area for electrochemical reactions. Additionally, the 1D oriented carbon fibers are cross-linked with each other, and it effectively eliminates the contact resistance between these fibers. The S/CHPCF cathode showed an excellent C-rate performance of 535 mAh g−1 up to 15 C, and 0.076% capacity attenuation per cycle at 5 C during 500 cycles (Fig. 14d). To further improve the e− conductivity of MOF-derived carbon hosts for Li–S batteries, Liu et al. reported a novel interpenetrated and self-standing conductive framework (ISCF) by the coupling of intertwined CNTs and strung HKUST-1-derived porous carbon polyhedrons [163]. Fig. 14(e) shows the fabrication process of a S@ISCF composite film. The self-standing HKUST-1/CNT hybrid film was firstly synthesized via interweaving the positively charged copper hydroxide nano-strands (CHN) and pre-treated negatively charged CNTs followed by immersion in H3BTC solution. This composite precursor was then pyrolyzed at 800 °C to yield the ISCF thin film. The self-standing electrode design enables a mitigation of volume variation of sulfur electrode (Fig. 14f). The HKUST-1-derived porous carbon polyhedrons ensure a uniform sulfur distribution, strong sulfur confinement and abundant electrode/electrolyte interfaces for fast Li+/e− transfer (Fig. 14g). What is more, the CNT penetration enriches the inner space of HKUST-1-derived porous carbon polyhedrons with more active interfaces for sulfur-based electrochemistry inside the pores. Additionally, the intertwined CNT network boosts the interfacial contact between polyhedrons. Thanks to these advantages, the S@ISCF electrode achieved an excellent cyclability over 500 cycles at 1C, an outstanding rate capability up to 10C, a high areal capacity of 6.23 mAh cm−2 and an ultra-high volumetric capacity of 960 Ah L−1 (Fig. 14h). 6.4 The derivatives of Ni-based MOFs as matrix for polar materials Hierarchical structure constructed from low-dimensional nanostructured building blocks is a desired architecture as sulfur host for Li–S batteries [63,164]. The sulfur host composed of Ni-MOF-derived hierarchical carbon spheres and MoS2 ultrathin nanosheets (MoS2@HCS hybrid) was synthesized by Hu and coauthors (Fig. 15 a) [165]. HCS was obtained via the carbonization of Ni-MOF at 800 °C in Ar atmosphere, and then the polar MoS2 nanosheets were formed on the surface of HCS in order to yield MoS2@HCS after annealing at 700 °C. The HCS constructed from building blocks of hollow carbon nanobubbles (Fig. 15b, c) can accommodate large volumetric expansion of sulfur upon lithiation. The polar MoS2 nanosheets throughout HCS (Fig. 15d) can effectively adsorb polysulfides, decrease the polysulfide shuttling effect and prolong the lifetime of cell. Benefiting from the job-sharing effects, the S/MoS2@HCS electrode delivered excellent reversible capacities of 1047, 902, 775 and 700 mAh g−1 at 0.2, 0.5, 1 and 2 C, respectively, and high capacity retention of 643 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 0.5 C (Fig. 15e). Very recently, Cheng et al. designed a novel nickel phosphide nanoporous composite derived from MOF-74(Ni) as sulfur host material [166]. Fig. 15(f) illustrates the synthesis of Ni2P/NC composite and its inner structure. After carbonization and phosphorization at PH3/Ar atmosphere, the MOF-74(Ni) was converted into uniformly distributed Ni2P nanoparticles in bulk conductive carbon network (NC) (Fig. 15g), which can effectively inhibit the escape of lithium polysulfides from the cathode host through the strong chemical bonding with Ni2P nanodots (Fig. 15h). The 3D conductive skeleton with abundant mesoporous structure can offer enough space to accommodate sulfur species and physically restrict the occurring of shuttle effect during cycle process. Such an advanced structure is beneficial to the acceleration of e− transport and conversion reaction even under high sulfur loading. The S@Ni2P/NC electrode exhibited a high initial capacity of 1357 mAh g−1 and a reversible capacity of 946 mAh g−1 over 300 cycles, as well as excellent electrochemical activity (918 mAh g−1) and enhanced cycling stability (300 cycles) even under high sulfur loading up to 4.6 mg cm−2 (Fig. 15i). 7 Conclusions and outlook The commercialization of Li–S batteries is impeded by several challenges, such as, the insulating nature of sulfur and discharged products (Li2S2 and Li2S), the solubility of long-chain polysulfides and the volume variation of sulfur cathode upon cycling. Recently, the carbon-based derivatives from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have emerged as unique cathode hosts for Li–S batteries. They not only have good conductivity and high porosity to accelerate Li+/e− transfer and accommodate volumetric expansion of sulfur cathode during charging/discharging process, but also have controllable chemical active sites that can adsorb polysulfides and enhance their conversion reaction kinetics. The synthetic methods, formation process and morphology, structural superiority, and electrochemical performance of MOFs-derived carbon strongly depend on the choice of MOF types. The parameter and performance comparisons of these carbon-based derivatives as Li–S cathode host are shown in Table 1 . There are some featured points required to emphasize: (1) The doped nitrogen atoms in ZIF-8-derived carbon can serve as Lewis base “catalyst” sites to enhance the adsorbability to lithium polysulfides. (2) The encapsulated cobalt atoms in N-doped carbon derived from ZIF-67 or Prussian blue analogue as graphitization promoter can improve the overall conductivity of carbon matrix and facilitate the rate of conversion reaction among S8, Li2Sn and Li2S2/Li2S. (3) The metal sulfides (e.g. Co9S8 derived from ZIF-67), metal carbides (e.g. Fe3C derived from Prussian blue) and metal oxides (e.g. Co3O4 derived from ZIF-67 or NiONiCo2O4 derived from Prussian blue analogue) can further modulate the binding energy with polysulfides and alleviate the “shuttle effect”. (4) The firm anchoring of MOFs grains enables a finer combination of their pyrolyzed carbon with extraneous long-range conductive carbon (e.g. CNTs, rGO and 3D graphene foam), leading to more optimized conductive nework to accelerate the Li+/e− transfer and improve the utilization of sulfur. The MOF precursors containing potential catalysis elements (e.g. Co, Fe, Mn, Ti) appear to be more effective on boosting the Li–S battery performance. They can be converted into the carbon skeletons decorated by transition metal, metal oxide or metal sulfide, which can serve as polar materials to chemically or electrostatically adsorb polysulfide intermediates. Moreover these transition metals likely catalyze the growth of carbon nanotubes and roughen the carbon surface, leading to the further increase of specific surface area of carbon framework. Although the carbon-based derivatives from MOFs have prominent superiority, there are still some challenges to the practical application of Li–S batteries. For instance, according to the data of Table 1, more than half of these sulfur electrodes have relatively low areal sulfur loading (< 2 mg cm−2) and high Electrolyte/Sulfur (E/S) ratio (> 10 µL mg−1). Furthermore, many reported synthetic strategies are difficult to scale up in industry due to expensive raw materials, complex production processes and toxic solvent. In addition, the electrochemical performance is not taken into account under high temperature, high pressure, corrosion and other harsh conditions. In order to solve these shortcomings, there is a long way to go. Fortunately, researchers all over the world have made great efforts to achieve the wide application of Li–S batteries, and have made exciting breakthroughs in the past research stage, especially in the area of carbon-based derivatives from MOFs as cathode host. Actually, MOF derivatives can be extended to more strategies to optimize the electrochemical performance of Li–S batteries in the future development. For example, they can be used to decorate or strengthen the separator, to function as electrolyte additives or to protect lithium metal anode against dendrite growth. We hope that this review will inspire the more rational design of practical Li–S batteries and provide an effective pathway for their commercialization. Lett. 137 2014 52 55 Qingping Wu gained his B.S. degree in 2016 in the School of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology. He is currently a joint-training Ph.D. candidate at East China University of Science and Technology and Shanghai Institute of Ceramics. His research interests focus on MOF-based materials, advanced energy storage/conversion, Li–S batteries and Li metal anodes. Fahai Cao received his Ph.D. in 1996 at East China University of Science and Technology. He is now a professor in East China University of Science and Technology. His research interests include energy storage in secondary batteries, C1 chemical industry and coal chemical industry. Chilin Li received his Ph.D. in 2008 at Fudan University. He is now a professor in Shanghai Institute of Ceramics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. His research interests include fluoride-based materials, Li and Mg metal batteries and solid state batteries.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (Li–S batteries) are promising candidates for the next generation high-energy rechargeable Li batteries due to their high theoretical specific capacity (1672 mAh g−1) and energy density (2500 Wh kg−1). The commercialization of Li–S batteries is impeded by several key challenges at cathode side, e.g. the insulating nature of sulfur and discharged products (Li2S2 and Li2S), the solubility of long-chain polysulfides and volume variation of sulfur cathode upon cycling. Recently, the carbon-based derivatives from metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has emerged talent in their utilization as cathode hosts for Li–S batteries. They are not only highly conductive and porous to enable the acceleration of Li+/e− transfer and accommodation of volumetric expansion of sulfur cathode during cycling, but also enriched by controllable chemical active sites to enable the adsorption of polysulfides and promotion of their conversion reaction kinetics. In this review, based on the types of MOFs (e.g. ZIF-8, ZIF-67, Prussian blue, Al-MOF, MOF-5, Cu-MOF, Ni-MOF), the synthetic methods, formation process and morphology, structural superiority of MOFs-derived carbon frameworks along with their electrochemical performance as cathode host in Li–S batteries are summarized and discussed.
